title-group.article-title: Heterotopic Ossification and Delayed Foreign Body Reaction after Hyoid Suspension for Obstructive Sleep Apnea

body.p: Heterotopic ossification (HO) is generally associated with musculoskeletal trauma, but this report presents a case of HO after hyoid suspension. This was associated with delayed onset of symptoms that resolved after resection of the focus of ossification.

A 61-year-old female was referred for evaluation of a persistent submental draining wound. Her medical history was significant for moderate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), intolerance to positive airway pressure therapy, and surgical treatment 4 years prior. Surgical treatment included uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, tongue stabilization, and hyomandibular suspension using the Repose system (now AIRvance; Medtronic, Inc, Minneapolis, Minnesota). Initial recovery was uneventful, but 30 months postoperatively she developed submental pain, edema, and incisional drainage. Over the course of the next year, multiple courses of oral and intravenous antibiotics, extending up to 1 month in duration, produced only short-term resolution of the pain and drainage.

Computed tomography revealed a 3 cm long bony process extending superoanteriorly from the left side of the central portion of the hyoid bone (Figure 1). There were no fluid collections. The patient was referred to the senior author (EJK) for evaluation.

caption.p: Image 1 (computerized tomography): CT image showing heterotopic ossification extending from the hyoid bone.

body.p: In the operating room, the hyoid bone was approached through a transcervical incision. The hyoid suspension sutures were intact. A small amount of central hyoid bone erosion (<20% of width) under the suture created laxity in the suture suspension. Over 1 cm away from this area of bony erosion, the bony process seen on preoperative imaging was identified, extending from the left side of the hyoid medial to the lesser cornu. Dissection revealed this bony process encased the Prolene suture that was part of the hyoid suspension; the suture extended from the hyoid bone to the screw planed in the mandible, although the bony process had only formed on the inferior half of this segment of suture. The bony process and the portion of the suture in the immediate area were resected. There were no complications during the surgery, and the patient healed uneventfully.

Gross examination of the bony fragments by pathology revealed hard, white-tan material encasing suture. Histologic evaluation of the bony material revealed lamellar and woven bone (Figure 2). Lamellar bone (Figure 2, right) is characterized by parallel deposition of collagen fibers, while woven bone (Figure 2, left) shows irregular and haphazard architecture with excess cement lines. Woven bone is an abnormal finding in adults and is part of reaction to injury and healing. Within this abnormal bony formation, fragments of polarizable material, compatible with suture, were identified. The clinical and histologic findings are consistent with HO as a result of chronic injury with the suture acting as a nidus.

caption.p: Image 2 (H&E): Lamellar bone (right side) characterized by parallel collagen deposition and woven bone (left side) with a haphazard collagen deposition.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: HO, also known as ectopic ossification or myositis ossificans, is the formation of true bone in atypical areas, usually in soft tissues.1 There are 3 types of heterotopic calcification: myositis ossificans progressiva, neurogenic heterotopic ossification, and traumatic heterotopic ossification; the latter is the most common and tends to occur after musculoskeletal injury.1 The trauma, inflammation, and venous stasis with invasive procedures or injury may release bone morphogenic protein and/or osteoprogenitor cells that can seed heterotopic bone formation.1,2

Surgical treatment of OSA includes the hyoid suspension procedure, which has relatively few complications.3,4 Infection unresponsive to antibiotics can occur after thyrohyoid or hyomandibular suspension,3 generally considered due to foreign body infection (personal communication with Dr Nico de Vries, May 2006), potentially explaining the partial erosion of the central hyoid bone underlying the suture material.

HO has not been reported after hyoid suspension; however, HO in the head and neck has been described in the trachea post-tracheostomy in a mechanically ventilated patient5 and in the setting of stylohyoid ossification (Eagle’s Syndrome). HO can occur in soft tissues without obligate proximity of bony structures, although in this case, typical for traumatic HO, proximity to bone supports the seeding theory regarding bone formation.2 Another theory explaining HO is that surgery, chronic inflammation, or trauma activates pluripotential progenitor cells, resulting in bone formation.2 The patient’s history would be consistent with either theory.

The University of California, San Francisco Committee on Human Research (institutional review board) does not require approval for case reports. However, we have obtained written consent from the patient for the use of this case and images in publications and presentations.
